articles.headline: G.M. Asks Its Chief to Resign
articles.snippet: The move to replace Fritz Henderson, who had appeared to be making some headway, stunned the auto industry.
articles.abstract: The move to replace Fritz Henderson, who had appeared to be making some headway, stunned the auto industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  As part of his bid to make General Motors management appear more accessible and responsive coming out of bankruptcy, the chief executive, Fritz Henderson, set up a Web page called Tell Fritz.

articles.headline: Obama Adds Troops, but Maps Exit Plan
articles.snippet: President Obama said he would begin to draw U.S. forces out of Afghanistan in July 2011, even after sending some 30,000 more troops by mid-2010.
articles.abstract: President Obama said he would begin to draw U.S. forces out of Afghanistan in July 2011, even after sending some 30,000 more troops by mid-2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y.  President Obama announced Tuesday that he would speed 30,000 additional troops to Afghanistan in coming months, but he vowed to start bringing American forces home in the middle of 2011, saying the United States could not afford and should not have to shoulder an open-ended commitment.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: A Victory for Holders of Yukos
articles.snippet: Shareholders in the former Yukos oil company, which was disbanded by the Russian government, will be able to seek monetary damages from the Russian government.
articles.abstract: Shareholders in the former Yukos oil company, which was disbanded by the Russian government, will be able to seek monetary damages from the Russian government.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  An arbitration panel has ruled that shareholders in the former Yukos oil company, which was disbanded by the Russian government in 2007, are entitled to seek an estimated $100 billion in damages from the Russian government, lawyers for the Yukos shareholders said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: A Quaking Brings No Collapse
articles.snippet: In the week after Dubai World told its creditors they wouldn’t be getting all their money back, two lessons about the global economy have emerged.
articles.abstract: In the week after Dubai World told its creditors they wouldn’t be getting all their money back, two lessons about the global economy have emerged.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the troubles in Dubai, you could reasonably have thought that the financial part of the financial crisis was over.

articles.headline: With Troop Pledge, New Demands on Afghans
articles.snippet: A commitment to redouble the campaign leaves unanswered a decisive question: Will the Afghans step up?
articles.abstract: A commitment to redouble the campaign leaves unanswered a decisive question: Will the Afghans step up?
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s commitment Tuesday night to redouble America’s campaign in Afghanistan left unanswered what is perhaps the most decisive question of all: will the Afghans step up too?

articles.headline: Surviving NBC’s Upheaval
articles.snippet: Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal at the center of a plan to shift control of the company from General Electric to Comcast, would presumably have to prove himself again to his new potential bosses.
articles.abstract: Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal at the center of a plan to shift control of the company from General Electric to Comcast, would presumably have to prove himself again to his new potential bosses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under Jeff Zucker’s guidance in the last few years, NBC Universal’s USA Network has become a powerhouse on cable, Bravo and Syfy have become branded destinations with their own distinctive programming and MSNBC has emerged as the liberal counterpoint to Fox News.

articles.headline: In Denmark, Ambitious Plan for Electric Cars
articles.snippet: A big tax break may draw buyers, but it is not certain they can be persuaded to make the switch.
articles.abstract: A big tax break may draw buyers, but it is not certain they can be persuaded to make the switch.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN  Is saving $40,000 at the showroom enough to get drivers behind the wheel of an electric car? With a program in the works to add easy access to charging stations, Denmark is about to find out.

articles.headline: Two Messages for Two Sides
articles.snippet: President Obama’s speech was an announcement of both an escalation and a plan to end the war in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s speech was an announcement of both an escalation and a plan to end the war in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama went before the nation on Tuesday night to announce that he would escalate the war in Afghanistan. And Mr. Obama went before the nation to announce that he had a plan to end the war in Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: A November With Rosier Retail Data
articles.snippet: Despite reports of weaker spending on the Friday after Thanksgiving, the nation’s stores appear to have fared much better this November than last year.
articles.abstract: Despite reports of weaker spending on the Friday after Thanksgiving, the nation’s stores appear to have fared much better this November than last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite reports of weaker spending on the Friday after Thanksgiving, the nation’s stores appear to have fared much better this November than last year  when consumers were so spooked by the deteriorating economy that they essentially went into hiding.

articles.headline: Afghans and Pakistanis Concerned Over U.S. Plan
articles.snippet: Diplomats scrambled to reassure the nations at the center of President Obama’s war strategy that the U.S. would not cut and run.
articles.abstract: Diplomats scrambled to reassure the nations at the center of President Obama’s war strategy that the U.S. would not cut and run.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Obama’s timetable for American forces in Afghanistan rattled nerves in that country and in Pakistan on Wednesday, as American diplomats worked to convince the two countries at the center of the president’s war strategy that the United States would not cut and run.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Carlotta Gall
